critique: This document pertains to the inspection of income tax returns under the Tariff Act of 1913. It outlines the conditions under which these returns can be inspected, primarily focusing on the role of the President and the Secretary of the Treasury in setting the rules and regulations. The document itself doesn't directly address ideological issues, immigration, or civil liberties. It mainly concerns government access to financial information. The order seems to balance federal and state access, as it allows state officers to access returns upon the governor's request. It doesn't expand executive power significantly, as it requires the Secretary of the Treasury to prescribe rules and regulations approved by the President. The document has minimal impact on economic regulation or social inclusion. Therefore, most scores should be neutral.
